awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Gemini Planet Imager Exoplanet Survey
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Gemini Planet Imaging (GPI) exoplanet survey, which is an extensive observational project using a new instrument to obtain images and spectra of extrasolar planets.  The data will be used to directly image Jovian planets (Jupiter-mass gas giants) around other stars, and measure the chemical composition of the planets? atmospheres.  The results will be used to test models of planet formation and evolution.  The funding will train and mentor two graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar in research.   The team will also carry out public outreach with the SETI Institute.

The GPI instrument is a new coronagraphic integral field unit commissioned at the Gemini Observatory.  It is capable of detecting and spectroscopically characterizing young Jovian planets reaching 10 million times fainter than their parent star at separations as close as 0.2 arcseconds.  Direct imaging of planets will yield information on planets typically not, or rarely accessible, by other methods (such as radial velocity measurements, transit observations, and gravitational microlensing).  The investigators will target over 600 young stars of spectral type A-M, and use the data to test formation paths of giant planets, dynamical evolution constraints and explore the bridge between giant planets and brown dwarfs.

por.por_cntn:
More than 4000 extrasolar planets have now been discovered, but almost all indiretly by seeing their effects on the light of their parent star, and almost all orbiting very close to those stars. Using the Gemini Planet Imager (GPI) we can see planets directly. GPI's adaptive optics can cancel the distortions caused by the Earth's atmosphere, and it's masks can block and control the light of a bright star to reveal young glowing giant planets that are a million times fainter than it. Using GPI, we surveyed more than 500 young stars to look for their planetary system. We detected six such planets and four larger brown dwarfs (failed stars.) These incude 51 Eridani b - a young (26 million years) toddler version of our own Jupiter. In each system, we can measure the orbit of the planets, and use spectroscopy to measure their composition, detecting water, carbon monoxide, and methane in their hot dense atmospheres.  

With our large survey, we can also study how common Jupiter-like planets are. Our observations show that they're rare - no more than 25% of sunlike stars have a Jupiter-like planet orbiting them - another way in which our solar system is special. Giant planets are more common around larger stars, and the brown dwarfs seem to have formed differenty than planets. 

The techniques we developed under this program let us detect giant Jupiter-like planets. In the future, with extremely large telescopes on the ground or future space telescopes, we will be able to use the software and approaches we developed to search for Earthlike planets, and measure oxygen or other biological signatures in their atmosphere. 

We have also used GPI to understand how adaptive optics is influenced by the atmosphere. We can see the effects all the way from high-altitude jet stream winds, and of air rising from warm surfaces in the telescope dome. Based on this, the NSF's Gemini Observatory is working to improve the temperature control of their telescope, improving this flagship facility. We are also using these models to design "GPI 2.0" - an upgrade for the instrument that will move it to Gemini North in Hawaii.
